Authors:
Grit Walther, Kerstin Hoffmann, Kerstin Voigt, G. S.
d. Hoog, Martin Kirchmair, Lennart Olsson, George Newcombe, Csaba
Vágvölgyi, Sabine Telle, Franziska Dölz, Hansjörg Prillinger, Adam
Prazenica, Tamás Papp, Martin Eckart
Title:
Diversity, genotypic identification, ultrastructural and
phylogenetic characterization of zygomycetes from different ecological
habitats and climatic regions: Limitations and utility of nuclear
ribosomal DNA barcode markers.
Abstract:
Besides morphological criteria traditionally used in
taxonomy, molecular markers which could be useful as barcodes gain an
increasing interest in identification practice of fungi. The success of
unequivocal identification relies on the reasonable selection of
potential marker genes. The search of a candidate universally applicable
for fungal identification is subject of a constant controversary debate.
The aim of this study was to investigate the reliability of genes from
the ribosomal RNA cluster, small subunit (SSU) 18S and large subunit
(LSU) 28S ribosomal DNA (rDNA), internal transcribed spacer 1 and 2
interrupted by 5.8S rDNA. For this purpose a total of 98 fungal
specimens isolated from different ecological habitats in diverse
geographic regions localized among the northern hemisphere were
examined. Fungi comprise 68 mucoralean, two mortierellalean, one
kickxellalean zygomycetes and several ascomycetes and basidiomycetes;
both of the latter ones serving as comparative microorganisms. The
reconstruction and analysis of a dataset encompassing a total of 114
nucleotide sequences including ITS1-5.8S-ITS2 nucleotide sequences of
morphologically well-defined type strains suggest that the accessibility
of type strains which could serve as references are essential for
reliable results.
